articles.headline: Seeking Space, Well-to-Do Londoners Dig Deep
articles.snippet: Wealthy London homeowners who have run out of ways to expand have begun digging underground to put in pools, gyms and other additions.
articles.abstract: Wealthy London homeowners who have run out of ways to expand have begun digging underground to put in pools, gyms and other additions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — To compensate for the lack of natural light around his new basement swimming pool, one London homeowner installed an outdoor camera that projects real-time images of the changing sky onto the pool ceiling. To assuage the concerns of swimmers who hate cramped spaces, another resident dug down so far beneath the earth that his pool is 16 feet deep and has a high-diving board.

articles.headline: Solar Firm Aided by Federal Loans Shuts Doors
articles.snippet: A Silicon Valley maker of solar power arrays that was started with high hopes and $527 million in loans from the federal government said that it would cease operations.
articles.abstract: A Silicon Valley maker of solar power arrays that was started with high hopes and $527 million in loans from the federal government said that it would cease operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —  A Silicon Valley maker of solar power arrays that was started with high hopes and $527 million in loans from the federal government said on Wednesday that it would cease operations. The failure of the company — and the loss to taxpayers — is likely to renew the debate in Washington about the wisdom of clean energy subsidies and loan guarantees.

articles.headline: German Officials Alarmed by Ex-Rapper’s New Message: Jihad
articles.snippet: Denis Mamadou Cuspert, a former rapper, is accused of using inflammatory videos and fiery speeches to incite terrorism and violence against the West.
articles.abstract: Denis Mamadou Cuspert, a former rapper, is accused of using inflammatory videos and fiery speeches to incite terrorism and violence against the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The man German security officials call a major security risk looks like a figure from a rap video, especially with the tattoos on his hands. The right one says “STR8,” and the left one “Thug.”

articles.headline: In T-Mobile Suit, Consumers Are Central
articles.snippet: The Justice Department challenged a merger of AT&T and T-Mobile to spur competition and innovation, but analysts question whether T-Mobile’s independence will serve that goal.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department challenged a merger of AT&T and T-Mobile to spur competition and innovation, but analysts question whether T-Mobile’s independence will serve that goal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department, in the suit it filed Wednesday to block AT&T’s $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile, asserted that T-Mobile “places important competitive pressure” on the larger cellular carriers. Keeping T-Mobile away from AT&T, the government contends, will spur innovation and give consumers lower prices and more choice.

articles.headline: Honoring Sept. 11, With Care
articles.snippet: Marketers and advertisers have steered clear of past 9/11 anniversaries , but they are changing course as the 10th one nears.
articles.abstract: Marketers and advertisers have steered clear of past 9/11 anniversaries , but they are changing course as the 10th one nears.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Madison Avenue steered clear of events that marked the anniversary of 9/11, anxious that any participation could be perceived as exploitive.

articles.headline: Florida Shutting ‘Pill Mill’ Clinics
articles.snippet: Officials have implemented tougher laws in an effort to disrupt an illegal pipeline for prescription drugs like Oxycodone.
articles.abstract: Officials have implemented tougher laws in an effort to disrupt an illegal pipeline for prescription drugs like Oxycodone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Florida has long been the nation’s center of the illegal sale of prescription drugs: Doctors here bought 89 percent of all the Oxycodone sold in the country last year. At its peak, so many out-of-staters flocked to Florida to buy drugs at more than 1,000 pain clinics that the state earned the nickname “Oxy Express.”

articles.headline: China Benefits as U.S. Solar Industry Withers
articles.snippet: Some American, Japanese and European solar companies still have a technological edge over Chinese rivals, but seldom a cost advantage, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Some American, Japanese and European solar companies still have a technological edge over Chinese rivals, but seldom a cost advantage, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The bankruptcies of three American solar power companies in the last month, including Solyndra of California on Wednesday, have left China’s industry with a dominant sales position — almost three-fifths of the world’s production capacity — and rapidly declining costs.
